Description: Limestone panel: both sides of the panel have been covered with a grid, drawn in ink. At the far left of one side has been drawn the figure of a woman who stands facing right, holding an 'ankh' sign and the papyrus scepter of a goddess. Though now much faded, the drawing was very well executed. She has a Hellenistic-looking profile. Her position at the far left of the space suggests that she was meant to be part of a larger composition. The deity is given the dominant rightward-facing orientation, while her royal audience would have occupied the secondary position, facing left. The other side of the panel has a barely visible representation of a king.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Prof Walter B Emery
Curator's comments: Bibliography: 'Temples and Tombs' [exhibition catalogue] (American Federation of Arts, 2006), 76, cat no. 34.
Bibliographic references: Russmann 2001 / Eternal Egypt: Masterworks of Ancient Art from the British Museum (69)
Exhibition history: Exhibited: 2006 7 Sept-26 Nov, Oklahoma City Museum of Art, Temples & Tombs 2006 21 Dec-2007 18 Mar, Jackonsville, Cummer Museum of Art & Gardens, Temples & Tombs 2007 15 Apr-8 Jul, Raleigh, North Carolina Museum of Art, Temples & Tombs 2007 16 Nov-2008 10 Feb, New Mexico, Albuquerque Museum, Temples & Tombs
